{{Infobox boxer | name = Zab Judah | image = Zab Judah.jpg | caption = Judah in 2010 | realname = Zabdiel Judah | nickname = Super | height = 5 ft 7+1/2 in | reach = 72 in | weight = {{plainlist| *[[Light welterweight]] *[[Welterweight]] *[[Light middleweight]] }} | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|10|27}} | birth_place = [[Brownsville, Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 55 | wins = 44 | KO = 30 | losses = 9 | draws = | no contests = 2 }}
'''Zabdiel Judah''' (born October 27, 1977) is an American [[professional boxer]]. He is a multiple-time former world champion in two [[weight class (boxing)|weight classes]], having held the [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] and [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] [[junior welterweight]] titles between 2000 and 2004; the IBF junior welterweight title again in 2011; and the [[undisputed champion|undisputed]] [[welterweight]] title in 2005, which included a reign as the [[lineal championship|lineal]] champion from 2005 to 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/welter.htm|title=The Lineal Welterweight Champs|publisher=The Cyber Boxing Zone Encyclopedia}}</ref>
==Amateur career== Judah began boxing at the age of six and compiled an amateur record of 110–5. He was a two-time US national champion and three-time [[New York Golden Gloves]] Champion. He also won the 1996 [[Police Athletic League|PAL]] National Championship. Judah beat [[Ishe Smith]] and [[Hector Camacho, Jr.]], but lost to [[David Díaz (boxer)|David Díaz]] in the finals of the Olympic trials, thus failing to qualify for the Olympic boxing team.<ref name="Canadastar">{{cite web | url = http://www.canadastarboxing.com/Fighters/zab-judah-profile.htm | publisher = Canadastar Boxing | title = Zab Judah Profile and Bio | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070208013635/http://www.canadastarboxing.com/Fighters/zab-judah-profile.htm | archivedate = 8 February 2007 | accessdate = 19 March 2014}}</ref>
==Professional career== ===Light welterweight=== ====Early years==== Judah made his professional debut as an 18-year-old on September 20, 1996, in [[Miami, Florida]] and defeated Michael Johnson by [[technical knockout]] in the second round. On April 14, 1998, Judah defeated Angel Beltre in the second round.<ref name="Canadastar"/> Judah accidentally butted heads with Esteban Flores in a fight in March 1999. Flores was cut on his forehead, and the match was halted in the third round. The bout was originally recorded as a [[technical draw]], but the result was changed to a [[No contest (boxing)|no contest]] in May 1999.
Judah then defeated [[Micky Ward]] by [[unanimous decision]] for the [[United States Boxing Association|USBA]] [[Light Welterweight]] title. He successfully defended the USBA title by stopping [[Darryl Tyson]] in the eleventh round on October 15, 1998.<ref name="Canadastar"/>
====IBF champion==== Judah defeated [[Wilfredo Negron]] in January 1999 with a fourth-round knockout to win the [[Interim championship|Interim]] [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] Light Welterweight title.<ref name="Canadastar"/> On February 12, 2000, he defeated Jan Piet Bergman to win the vacant IBF Light Welterweight title. Bergman went down twice in the first round, but recovered in the second round, knocking Judah down. Judah knocked out Bergman in the fourth round to win the title.<ref>{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Timothy | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Defeats Bergman for Title | work =[[The New York Times]] | publisher = | date =February 13, 2000 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0DEFD71631F930A25751C0A9669C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 9, 2008 }}</ref> On June 20, 2000, Judah made his first title defense against [[Junior Witter]] in [[Glasgow, Scotland]]. It was an awkward fight for Judah, as Witter rarely engaged in an extended exchange of punches. Witter frequently switched between fighting right-handed and left-handed, making him an elusive opponent. Judah's consistent body punching slowed Witter down, and in the fifth round, Judah caught Witter with a straight left hand that hurt Witter and sent his mouthpiece skittering across the ring. Judah defeated Witter by unanimous decision.<ref name="Witter">{{cite news | last = Smith | first = Timothy W. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Wins in Title Defense | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =June 20, 2000 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0DEFD71631F930A25751C0A9669C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 9, 2008 }}</ref>
Two months later, on August 5, 2000, at the Mohegan Sun in Connecticut, Judah defeated former IBF Light Welterweight Champion [[Terron Millett]] by fourth-round knockout. Judah was knocked down in the first round from a left hand. Judah rose quickly, and from that point on he dominated the fight. Judah hurt Millett with two [[striking combination|combinations]] near the end of the first round. In round two, Judah sent Millett down with a right hand to the chin. Millett survived the round, but he was clearly hurt. In round four, Judah charged across the ring and inflicted a series of blows on Millett, knocking him down again. Millett got up, but Judah continued his assault and knocked Millett down again. Millett rose at the count of four, but his legs were unsteady and the referee decided to stop the bout.<ref name="Millett">{{cite news | last =Brown | first =Clifton | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Retains Title With Knockout of Former Champion | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =August 5, 2000 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9400E1DD133CF935A3575BC0A9669C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 9, 2008 }}</ref>
In his third title defense, Judah stopped Hector Quiroz in the eighth round on October 20, 2000, at [[The Palace of Auburn Hills]] in [[Auburn Hills, Michigan]].<ref name="Canadastar"/> On January 13, 2001, Judah defeated Reggie Green by tenth-round technical knockout at the Mohegan Sun in Connecticut. Judah had trouble landing punches effectively against Green for the majority of the fight, but in round ten, he knocked Green down with a left [[Hook (boxing)|hook]]. Green beat the count, but Judah then ran across the ring and sent Green down to the canvas with a right hand, forcing the referee to stop the fight.<ref>{{cite news | last =Cavanaugh | first =Jack | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Struggles But Stops Green in 10 | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =January 14, 2001 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CEFD8153DF937A25752C0A9679C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 9, 2008 }}</ref> On June 23, 2001, Judah defeated Allan Vester by third-round knockout in his fifth successful defense of the IBF title. In round two, Judah put Vester down to the canvas twice. In the third round, Judah knocked out Vester with a left hand that connected on Vester's temple. Vester went down on his knees and nearly lost his mouthpiece. The referee stopped the fight right before the closing bell. The fight would set up a unification match between Judah and [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] and [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] Light Welterweight Champion [[Kostya Tszyu]], who defeated [[Oktay Urkal]] on the undercard.<ref>{{cite news | last =Wong | first =Edward | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah and Tszyu Win, Setting Up Unification | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =June 24, 2001 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9402EEDE1330F937A15755C0A9679C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 9, 2008 }}</ref>
====Judah vs. Tszyu==== The much anticipated matchup between Judah and Tsyzu took place on November 3, 2001, at the [[MGM Grand Las Vegas|MGM Grand]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] for the [[List of undisputed boxing champions#Junior Welterweight|Undisputed Light Welterweight Championship]]. Judah entered the fight as a 3-to-1 favorite to win.<ref name="CBZ">{{cite web | last =Bushnell | first =Chris | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Tsyzu Levels Judah With One Punch | work = | publisher =Cyber Boxing Zone | date = | url =http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxingchronicle/articles_tszyujudah.html | doi = | accessdate =May 10, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="ESB">{{cite web | last =Frank | first =Gonzalez | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Sharkie's Week in Boxing: Who says nice guys never win? | work = | publisher =East Side Boxing | date =November 5, 2001 | url =http://www.eastsideboxing.com/KostyaTszyuvsZabJudah.html | doi = | accessdate =May 10, 2008 }}</ref> With 10 seconds left to go in round two, Tszyu landed a right hand clean on Judah's chin and he backed away from Tszyu with his hands down. Tszyu went after Judah, throwing another right hand that landed on his chin and sent Judah crashing to the canvas. Judah jumped up instinctively and tried to signal that he was fine to referee [[Jay Nady]], but was still dazed by the punch and fell down a second time. When Judah collapsed, Nady waved the fight over, resulting in a technical knockout victory for Tsyzu and Judah's first professional loss.<ref name="CBZ"/>
While Tszyu celebrated in his corner, Judah was in disbelief of what just happened and became infuriated.<ref name="ESB"/> Judah picked up his stool and hurled it towards center ring. While being restrained by his father and trainer, [[Yoel Judah]], he broke loose and walked up to Nady and stuck his gloved fist into his neck and had to be pulled off by cornermen. A few minutes later, Jimmy Lennon, Jr. announced the official decision and Judah screamed out and again had to be restrained by a growing number of security guards and cornermen.<ref name="CBZ"/> Judah was fined [[United States dollar|$]]75,000 and suspended for six months by the [[Nevada State Athletic Commission]].<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Fined $75,000 And Suspended | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =December 1, 2001 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DE5DC103DF932A35751C1A9679C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 10, 2008 }}</ref>
After defeating Omar Weis by unanimous decision in July 2002, Judah challenged [[DeMarcus Corley]] for the [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] Light Welterweight title on July 12, 2003, at the [[Orleans Hotel and Casino]] in Las Vegas. Judah knocked Corley down with a left hand in the third round en route to defeating Corley by [[split decision]]. Judah broke his left hand during the fight. In his only defense of the WBO title, Judah knocked out Jaime Rangel in the first round on December 13, 2003.<ref name="Canadastar"/>
===Welterweight=== ====Judah vs. Spinks==== On April 10, 2004, at the [[Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino]] in Las Vegas, Judah fought [[Cory Spinks]] for the [[List of undisputed boxing champions#Welterweight|Undisputed Welterweight Championship]]. Judah had trouble at the start figuring out how to fight Spinks, the taller fighter. He could not move forward to get inside, but was having success moving laterally. Spinks scored a knockdown in the eleventh round, but Judah came back and put Spinks down to the canvas in the final round. In the end, Spinks defeated Judah by unanimous decision with scores of 114–112 twice and 116–111.<ref name="Spinks">{{cite news | last =Katz | first =Mike | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Klitschko Knocked Out; Spinks Survives | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =April 11, 2004 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E0DE1138F932A25757C0A9629C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 11, 2008 }}</ref>
For the rest of 2004, Judah defeated [[Rafael Pineda (boxer)|Rafael Pineda]] by split decision and Wayne Martell by first-round technical knockout.
====Judah vs. Spinks II==== On February 5, 2005, Judah would get a rematch with Spinks at the [[Savvis Center]] in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], Spinks' hometown. The fight was the first major bout in St. Louis in more than 40 years, and it was a sellout. Judah was the aggressor throughout the fight. He knocked Spinks down to his knees at the bell in the seventh round, but it was not ruled a knockdown. Spinks had a strong start to the ninth round and connected with a left hand, then followed with a right hand and a combination, but Judah scored a knockdown moments later. Judah pressed the attack after the first knockdown and avoided Spinks' desperate efforts to [[Clinch hold|tie him up]]. After Spinks was knocked down for the second time, the referee stopped the fight, and Judah became the new [[Undisputed Champion|Undisputed]] [[Welterweight]] Champion.<ref name="Spinks 2">{{cite news | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Takes Spinks's Title To Ruin His Homecoming | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =February 6, 2005 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9501E7DD1E3BF935A35751C0A9639C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 11, 2008 }}</ref>
====Undisputed welterweight champion==== In his first fight as undisputed welterweight champion, he fought [[Cosme Rivera]] on May 14, 2005, at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas. Judah sent Rivera down with a straight left hand to the face less than 30 seconds into the bout. Rivera beat the count, but was knocked down again about 10 seconds later. Judah hit Rivera hard several times in the second round, and in the third round, he connected with a left uppercut, that caused Rivera to stagger backwards and fall into the ropes before hitting the canvas. Rivera rose at the count of five, but he was badly hurt and the referee stopped the fight.<ref name="Rivera">{{cite news | last =Brown | first =Clifton | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =With Quick Victory, Judah Shows Belt Fits Just Fine | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =May 15, 2005 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/15/sports/othersports/15judah.html?_r=1&oref=slogin | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 12, 2008 }}</ref>
His next fight took place on January 7, 2006 at [[Madison Square Garden]] in New York City against [[Carlos Baldomir]]. For Judah, the fight was viewed as a tuneup bout that would lead to a lucrative bout between Judah and [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] Light Welterweight Champion [[Floyd Mayweather, Jr.]], which was tentatively scheduled for April.<ref name="tuneup">{{cite news | last =Abramson | first =Mitch | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah Turned a Tuneup Fight at Home Into a Career Setback | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =January 9, 2006 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/09/sports/othersports/09boxing.html | doi = | accessdate =May 12, 2008 }}</ref> Judah entered the fight as a 10-to-1 favorite over Baldomir.<ref>{{cite web | last =Canobbio | first =Bob | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Baldomir vs. Mayweather: CompuBox Pre-Fight Analyst | work = | publisher =[[HBO]] Boxing | date = | url =http://www.hbo.com/boxing/events/2006/1104_baldomir_mayweather/columns/compubox_pre.html | doi = | accessdate =May 12, 2008 }}</ref> The stage was set when Judah unsportingly punched Baldomir on the thigh during the prefight introductions instead of touching gloves to show [[sportsmanship]]. The early rounds of the fight were close, but as the rounds passed, Judah was doing less than necessary to win, while Baldomir kept applying pressure on Judah.<ref>{{cite web | last =Gonzalez, Jr. | first =Frank | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Carlos Baldomir Takes WBC Title From Judah! | work = | publisher =East Side Boxing | date =January 6, 2006 | url =http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=5736&more=1 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 12, 2008 }}</ref> In round seven, Judah was hurt by a right hand and Baldomir landed a series of right hands to Judah's head along the ropes during the tenth round. Baldomir defeated Judah by unanimous decision with scores of 115–113, 114–113 and 115–112 from the three judges.<ref>{{cite news | last =Abramson | first =Mitch | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Baldomir Upsets Judah | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =January 8, 2006 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9500EFDC1F30F93BA35752C0A9609C8B63 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 12, 2008 }}</ref>
''[[Ring Magazine|The Ring]]'' named Baldomir's victory over Judah the [[Ring Magazine upsets of the year|upset of the year]] for 2006. Judah's IBF and WBA belts were not on the line, because Baldomir did not pay sanctioning fees to the IBF and WBA.<ref name="tuneup" /> Baldomir did win the [[Lineal championship|lineal]], WBC and ''The Ring'' titles, while the WBA (Super) title was vacated after Judah's loss (WBA (Regular) titleholder [[Luis Collazo]] became the sole WBA Champion), but the IBF still recognized him as their champion.<ref>{{cite web | last =Lumpin | first =John | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Alphabet Rules | work = | publisher =SecondsOut.com | date = | url =http://www.secondsout.com/news/index.cfm?ccs=534&cs=24607 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 12, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxing.com/cory_spinks_vs_zab_judah.html|title=Zab Judah vs. Cory Spinks II - Boxing.com|website=www.boxing.com|access-date=2017-02-04}}</ref>
====Judah vs. Mayweather==== {{Main article|Floyd Mayweather Jr. vs. Zab Judah}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Copy of MayweathervsJudah38.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Zab Judah throws a punch at Floyd Mayweather]] --> With the loss to Baldomir, it appeared that Judah's much anticipated bout with Mayweather was off, but Judah's promoter [[Don King (boxing promoter)|Don King]] and Mayweather's promoter [[Bob Arum]] reworked the deals so the fight would go on. Mayweather was scheduled to earn a minimum $6 million while Judah was to earn $3 million plus a percentage of the profits, but because of Judah's loss, Mayweather earned a minimum $5 million while Judah was guaranteed $1 million plus a percentage of profits above $7 million.<ref name="ESPN">{{cite web | last =Rafael | first =Dan | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah, Mayweather to fight in Vegas on April 8 | work = | publisher =[[ESPN.com]] | date =January 26, 2006 | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2300340 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 13, 2008 }}</ref> The fight took place on April 8, 2006, at the [[Thomas and Mack Center]] in Las Vegas.
Judah started strongly and put up a valiant fight, at times matching Mayweather's speed and punching precision.<ref name="USA Today">{{cite news | last =Johnson | first =Chuck | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Mayweather survives Judah's low blows to win IBF belt | work =[[USA Today]] | publisher = | date =April 9, 2006 | url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2006-04-09-mayweather-judah_x.htm | doi = | accessdate =May 13, 2008 }}</ref> It appeared that Judah scored a knockdown in the second round when Mayweather's glove touched the canvas; however, referee [[Richard Steele (referee)|Richard Steele]] ruled it a slip.<ref name="BraggingRightsCorner.com">{{cite web |last = Leanardi |first = Mike |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Mayweather Passes The Biggest Test of his Career |work = |publisher = BraggingRightsCorner.com |date = April 8, 2006 |url = http://www.braggingrightscorner.com/leanardimayweather040806.html |doi = |accessdate = May 13, 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080305141500/http://www.braggingrightscorner.com/leanardimayweather040806.html |archivedate = March 5, 2008 |df = }}</ref> In round four, Judah landed a right hand to the head that caused Mayweather to retreat to the ropes and cover up. The momentum changed in the fifth round, when Mayweather hurt Judah with a combination to the face. Then Mayweather landed a right hand on the bridge of Judah's nose, and blood began to flow. The seventh round was the most dominant for Mayweather to that point. Once again, he drew blood from Judah's nose. A combination from Mayweather backed Judah into a corner, and Judah's foot movement was considerably slower than it had been earlier in the fight.<ref name="Times Mayweather">{{cite news | last =Brown | first =Clifton | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Mayweather Is Crowned, but Not Without a Fight | work =The New York Times | publisher = | date =April 9, 2006 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/09/sports/othersports/09boxing.html?_r=1&oref=slogin | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 15, 2008 }}</ref>
With about 10 seconds left in the tenth round, Judah hit Mayweather with a [[Groin attack|low blow]] and followed it with a right hand to the back of Mayweather's head. As Mayweather hopped around the ring in pain, Steele called time to give Mayweather a rest period. Mayweather's uncle and trainer, [[Roger Mayweather]], climbed into the ring and approached Judah.<!-- He DIDN'T try to choke him, check video and it's not in the reference --><ref name="BraggingRightsCorner.com"/> Yoel Judah entered the ring and threw a punch at Roger. At that point, members of both fighters' camps entered the ring and an all-out melee ensued. More than a dozen security officers and police officers rushed into the ring and managed to control the situation.<ref name="Times Mayweather"/> After the ring was cleared, Roger Mayweather was ejected from the fight. Mayweather cruised through the last two rounds on his way to a unanimous decision victory by scores of 116–112, 117–111 and 119–109.<ref name="BraggingRightsCorner.com"/>
After the fight, the purses for both fighters were withheld until video of the fight could be reviewed. Don King argued that Mayweather should have been disqualified because his uncle was the first person to enter the ring.<ref name="Times Mayweather"/> At an April 13 hearing, the Nevada State Athletic Commission fined Roger Mayweather $200,000 and revoked his boxing license for one year. At a hearing on May 8, the Commission disciplined the other offenders in the melee. It fined Yoel Judah $100,000 and revoked his license for one year, fined Mayweather cornerman Leonard Ellerbe $50,000 and suspended his license for four months, and fined Zab Judah $350,000 and revoked his license for one year.<ref>{{cite web |last = Berlin |first = David |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Boxing and the Law: Judah-Mayweather and Its Aftermath |work = |publisher = The Sweet Science |date = May 22, 2006 |url = http://www.thesweetscience.com/boxing-article/3822/boxing-law-judah-mayweather-its-aftermath/ |format = |doi = |accessdate = May 15, 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090107222856/http://www.thesweetscience.com/boxing-article/3822/boxing-law-judah-mayweather-its-aftermath/ |archivedate = January 7, 2009 |df = }}</ref>
====Return from suspension==== On April 13, 2007, Judah made his return to the ring against [[Rubén Galván (boxer)|Ruben Galvan]] at the [[Fitzgeralds Casino & Hotel Tunica|Fitzgeralds Casino & Hotel]] in [[Tunica, Mississippi]]. Judah came out strongly in the first round, landing numerous shots on Galvan. During the round, a bad cut opened near the top of Galvan's head. The referee called for a timeout to allow the doctor to take a look at the cut. Due to the severity of the cut, the fight was waved off. The cut was ruled to be caused by an accidental foul with an elbow and since the fight did not go past four rounds, the fight was ruled a no contest.<ref>{{cite web | last =Eberline | first =Richard | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Boxing Result: Zab Judah – Ruben Galvan | work = | publisher =SaddoBoxing.com | date =April 14, 2007 | url =http://www.saddoboxing.com/5074-zab-judah-ruben-galvan.html | doi = | accessdate =May 16, 2008 }}</ref>
====Judah vs. Cotto==== On June 9, 2007, Judah took on WBA [[Welterweight]] Champion [[Miguel Cotto]] in New York City before a soldout crowd at [[Madison Square Garden]].<ref name="ESPN Cotto">{{cite web | last =Rafael | first =Dan | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Cotto keeps crown on 11th-round knockout of Judah | work = | publisher =ESPN.com | date = | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=2899424&campaign=rss&source=ESPNHeadlines | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 16, 2008 }}</ref> In the first round, Cotto landed a low blow that put Judah to the canvas. Referee Arthur Mercante, Jr. offered a stern warning to Cotto. In the third round, Judah took yet another low blow from Cotto, which resulted in Cotto receiving a point deduction.<ref>{{cite web | last =Woods | first =Michael | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Pugilistic Pride Of P.R. Cotto Downs Zab | work = | publisher =The Sweet Science | date =June 9, 2007 | url =http://www.thesweetscience.com/boxing-article/5152/pugilistic-pride-cotto-downs-zab/ | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 16, 2008 }}</ref> Cotto and Judah delivered an all-action brawl, but after weathering some difficult early rounds as he figured out Judah's southpaw style and adjusted to his speed, Cotto took over the bout. In round seven, both fighters went toe-to-toe and in round eight he hurt Judah several times. In round nine, Judah took a knee to gain a breather from Cotto's aggressive style. By the tenth round, Judah was bleeding from a cut over his right eye and was hurt by an uppercut from Cotto that sent him retreating to the ropes, but Judah stayed upright. Early in the eleventh round, Cotto landed a combination that dropped Judah to the canvas. He managed to get to his feet, but Cotto went after Judah with a relentless attack, turning him sideways along the ropes as he continued to throw punches. That forced the referee to stop the fight.<ref name="ESPN Cotto"/>
Judah, who trailed 97–91 on all three scorecards, claimed he had been weakened by the two low blows early in the fight. He said, "The first low blow was very hard. The second one took a lot out of me. The low blows affected me from the time they hit me." Cotto earned $2.5 million plus a piece of the pay-per-view profits, while Judah earned $1 million plus a percentage of the profits.<ref name="ESPN Cotto"/>
Judah fought Edwin Vazquez at the [[Hard Rock Hotel and Casino (Biloxi)|Hard Rock]] resort in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]] on September 7, 2007. Despite suffering a cut over his left eye, Judah defeated the overmatched Vazquez by unanimous decision. Judah hurt Vazquez several times over the course of the contest, but he injured his left hand midway through the fight and was unable to finish off Vasquez.<ref>{{cite web | last =Rafael | first =Dan | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Scorecard: Witter makes bold statement by blasting out Harris | work = | publisher =ESPN.com | date =September 10, 2007 | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/columns/story?columnist=rafael_dan&id=3011677 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 16, 2008 }}</ref>
===Light middleweight=== On November 17, 2007 in Judah defeated Ryan Davis by unanimous decision. With the win, he won the vacant [[International Boxing Council|IBC]] [[light middleweight]] title. The fight took place at the Casablanca Casino in [[Providenciales]], [[Turks and Caicos Islands|Turks And Caicos Islands]] which had an open roof. In the third round it began to rain. Since there was no marquee covering the ring, both fighters continued to fight in the rain. During the third, Judah scored a knockdown on Davis, although he recovered, he went on to lose by a wide margin (119-109 119-109 118-110).
Judah was scheduled to fight [[Shane Mosley]] on May 31, 2008, at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas, but it was postponed after Judah needed 50 [[Surgical suture|stitches]] in his right arm after slipping in his bathroom and smashing it through a glass shower door.<ref>{{cite web | last =Rafael | first =Dan | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Judah's right arm injury forces postponement of Mosley fight | work = | publisher =ESPN.com | date =May 8, 2008 | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=3387139 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 16, 2008 }}</ref>
===Return to welterweight=== ====Judah vs. Clottey==== On August 2, 2008, Judah lost to [[Joshua Clottey]] by [[technical decision]] in a fight for the vacant IBF Welterweight title at the [[Palms Casino Resort]] in Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite web | last =Hale | first =Andreas | title =Clottey wins IBF 147 belt! | work = | publisher =Fightnews.com | date =August 2, 2008 | url =http://www.fightnews.com/fightnews_2/headlines//EkEZZkyAZyceRymAEu.html | doi = | accessdate =August 3, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080822001052/http://www.fightnews.com/fightnews_2/headlines/EkEZZkyAZyceRymAEu.html |archivedate = August 22, 2008}}</ref> Judah began the busier fighter, showing quick hands and throwing effective combinations behind a [[jab]]. Clottey began steadily closing the distance between himself and his opponent from the third round, landing an increasing number of punches that took their toll on Judah.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite web | last = | first = | title =Clottey defeats Judah to win IBF welterweight belt | work = | publisher =[[Reuters]] | date =August 3, 2008 | url =https://www.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUSSP14859720080803 | format = | doi = | accessdate =August 3, 2008 }}</ref> In round four, Clottey landed an uppercut that caused Judah to lose his balance, and by the end of the round, Judah had blood running down his nose.<ref name="Press">{{cite web | last = | first = | title =Joshua Clottey beats Zab Judah to win vacant IBF welterweight belt | work = | publisher =[[The Canadian Press]] | date =August 2, 2008 | url =http://canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5g7yRxGbn2bCzzwrJBpctSKNluGvg | format = | doi = | accessdate =August 3, 2008 }}</ref> Judah staged a comeback in the sixth round,<ref name="Reuters"/> but in the middle of the seventh round, Clottey landed a right hand that hurt Judah and caused him to back into a corner.<ref name="Seattle">{{cite web | last = | first = | title =Joshua Clottey beats Zab Judah to win vacant IBF welterweight belt | work = | publisher =''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' | date =August 2, 2008 | url =http://www.seattlepi.com/scorecard/othernews.asp?articleID=237513 | format = | doi = | accessdate =August 3, 2008 }}</ref> In round nine, Judah suffered a cut over his right eye and the fight was stopped after he said he could not see. The referee had ruled the cut was caused by an accidental clash of heads and so the fight went to the scorecards. Two judges scored the fight 86–85 and the other judge scored it 87–84, all in favor of Clottey.<ref name="Reuters"/>
====Comeback trail==== After the loss to Clottey, Judah fought Ernest Johnson on November 8, 2008, at Madison Square Garden in New York City. Judah dominated the bout early,<ref name="IHT">{{cite web | author =Associated Press | title =Judah, Salita score unanimous decisions | work = | publisher =''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' | date =August 9, 2008 | url =http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/11/09/sports/BOX-Calzaghe-Jones-Undercard.php | format = | doi = | accessdate =August 9, 2008 }}</ref> but in round three, Judah suffered two cuts from accidental head butts.<ref name="johnson">{{cite web | last =Rafael | first =Dan | title =Judah revitalizes career, earns unanimous decision over Johnson | work = | publisher =ESPN.com | date =August 9, 2008 | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=3690850 | format = | doi = | accessdate =August 9, 2008 }}</ref> Finding success with lead right hands and short left hands.<ref name="IHT"/> Judah won the bout by unanimous decision with scores of 99–91, 98–92 and 98–92.<ref name="johnson"/>
On November 6, 2009, Judah took on Ubaldo Hernandez from Mexico at Palms Resort, in Las Vegas, Nevada.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eurosport.com/boxing/hernandez-new-opponent-for-judah_sto2108504/story.shtml|title=Hernandez New Opponent for Judah|date=2009-10-31|newspaper=Eurosport|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> Judah won the fight by TKO in the second round.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xb36u1_zab-judah-vs-ubaldo-hernandez-k-o-a_sport|title=Zab Judah Vs Ubaldo Hernandez (K.O au 2rd) - vidéo Dailymotion|date=2009-11-09|website=Dailymotion|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref>
Judah was in line for a fight with [[Devon Alexander]], after the latter's win against [[Juan Urango]].<ref>{{cite web | last =Wells | first =Peter | title =Bradley vs. Abregu in June; Alexander vs. Judah later this year | work = | publisher =BoxingNews24.com | date =March 7, 2010 | url =http://www.boxingnews24.com/2010/03/alexander-stops-urango-zab-judah-could-be-next/ | accessdate =May 4, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last =Dower | first =Jim | title =Alexander stops Urango, Zab Judah could be next – News | work = | publisher =BoxingNews24.com | date =March 12, 2010 | url =http://www.boxingnews24.com/2010/03/bradley-vs-abregu-in-june-alexander-vs-judah-later-this-year/ | accessdate =May 4, 2010}}</ref> He has also been linked to a match with [[Timothy Bradley]], as he was considered as a possible replacement for [[Marcos Maidana]]. The former undisputed champion publicly challenged both of them on more than one occasion in 2010. Promoter Gary Shaw tried to begin negotiations with Judah for a potential bout in 2010.<ref>{{cite web | last =Reeno | first =Rick | title =Bradley's Promoter Wonders Where Zab Judah Has Gone | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =May 11, 2010 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=27690 | accessdate =May 11, 2010}}</ref> However, Judah declined the match but promised to fight Bradley and Alexander after a tune-up fight on July 16 at the [[Prudential Center]] in [[New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web | last =Vester | first =Mark | title =Judah Found: Says "Punk" Bradley, Alexander Will Get It | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =May 12, 2010 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=27713 | accessdate =May 12, 2010}}</ref>
The Brooklyn native's tune up fight in July was co-promoted by Main Events and Super Judah Promotions.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | title =Zab Judah Signs With Main Events, Returns in July | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =May 25, 2010 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=28054 | accessdate =May 26, 2010}}</ref> In June 2010, Judah expressed his intention in moving down to the light welterweight division after the upcoming fight, hoping to revitalize his career.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://espn.go.com/sports/boxing/notebook/_/id/5272877/zab-judah-moving-hopes-reviving-career | title =Judah moving on down to jump-start career | last =Rafael | first =Dan | work = | publisher =ESPN.com | date =June 12, 2010 | accessdate =June 13, 2010}}</ref> His opponent was [[Jose Armando Santa Cruz]] of Mexico (28–4; 17 KO).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxingnews24.com/2010/07/last-chance-for-zab-judah/ | title =Last Chance for Zab Judah? | last =Jackson | first =Kirk | work = | publisher =BoxingNews24.com | date =July 13, 2010 | accessdate =July 14, 2010}}</ref> Judah won the bout by TKO in round three.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=29316 | title =Zab Judah Stops Jose Armando Santa Cruz in Three | last =Vester | first =Mark | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =July 16, 2010 | accessdate =July 17, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/early-results-from-newark-3-53234 | title =Judah destroys Santa Cruz | last =Wolfheimer | first =Kurt | work = | publisher =FightNews.com | date =July 16, 2010 | accessdate =July 17, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=29323 | title =Zab Judah "Super" Once Again, Back in The 140 Picture | last =Songalia | first =Ryan | work = | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =July 17, 2010 | accessdate =July 17, 2010}}</ref>
===Return to light welterweight=== ====Judah vs. Matthysse==== On November 6, 2010, Judah won a [[split decision]] over previously undefeated [[Lucas Matthysse]] in a fight for the vacant regional [[North American Boxing Organization|NABO]] Light Welterweight title at the Prudential Center in [[Newark, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web |last =Richardson |first =Matt |title =Judah edges Matthysse |work = |publisher =Fightnews.com |date =November 6, 2010 |url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/early-results-from-newark-nj-4-65912 |accessdate =November 7, 2010}}</ref> The former world champion fought in the light welterweight division for the first time in almost seven years.
The Brooklyn native began the busier fighter, using the jab and trying to land uppercuts for the first two rounds, while Matthysse worked on the body. In round three, a clash of heads opened a cut outside of the left eye of Judah. Matthysse displayed more aggression and became the aggressor in the third and the fourth round and Judah switched to a defensive tactic. In the next two rounds, the American boxer picked up the pace, beginning to land more combinations. The seventh round was less active but in the eight, Judah landed some hard right counter shots. Judah continued to box throughout the ninth round but Matthysse began to show more power in the tenth, focusing on the head of his opponent and knocking down the American boxer after a hard right hand to the jaw. Judah got up but he was hurt, and the Argentine fighter tried to press the attack after the knockdown. However, Judah held and worked on the defensive and managed to finish the bout.<ref>{{cite web |last =Vester |first =Mark |title =Judah Rocked Bad, But Edges Matthysse To Win |work = |publisher =BoxingScene.com |date =November 7, 2010 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=32589 |accessdate =November 7, 2010}}</ref> Two judges scored the fight 114–113 for Judah, while the other judge scored it 114–113 for Matthysse.<ref>{{cite web |last =Coppinger |first =Mike |title =Zab Judah earns tough split decision over Lucas Matthysse |work = |publisher =USA Today.com |date =November 7, 2010 |url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2010-11-07-zab-judah-split-decision_N.htm |accessdate =November 16, 2010}}</ref>
====Second IBF title reign==== Following the win against Matthysse, negotiations for a fight against [[Kaizer Mabuza]] began. Both sides eventually agreed to a March 5 bout, with the vacant IBF Light Welterweight title on the line. Former champion [[Pernell Whitaker]] joined Judah's training camp to help him prepare for the match.<ref>{{cite web |last = |first = |title =Judah-Mabuza: Pernell Whitaker Helping Zab In Camp |work = |publisher =''BoxingScene'' |date =January 27, 2011 |url =http://www.boxingscene.com/judah-mabuza-pernell-whitaker-helping-zab-camp--35254 |accessdate =March 6, 2011}}</ref> Whitaker said: "I don't train guys to be like me. I help guys to do the things that work for them. If I can teach you how to hit and not get hit, that's a blessing for you. Zab has the same abilities I have, but Zab still has to put it together and do it the way that Zab knows how to do it."<ref>{{cite web |last =Velin |first =Bob |title =Zab Judah continues his personal road to redemption |work = |publisher =''USA Today'' |date =March 4, 2011 |url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2011-03-04-zab-judah_N.htm |accessdate =March 6, 2011}}</ref> On March 5, 2011, Judah defeated Mabuza via technical knockout in the seventh round, at the Prudential Center in Newark, New Jersey, claiming the IBF title again after almost ten years.<ref>{{cite web |last =Wolfheimer |first =Kurt |title =Judah wins IBF jr welter belt |work = |publisher =''Fight News'' |date =March 5, 2011 |url =http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/early-results-from-newark-nj-5-77476#more-77476 |accessdate =March 6, 2011}}</ref>
====Judah vs. Khan==== Judah fought [[World Boxing Association|WBA (Super)]] champion [[Amir Khan (British boxer)|Amir Khan]] in a unification bout on July 23, 2011 at [[Mandalay Bay|Mandalay Bay Resort & Casino]], Las Vegas. Judah was knocked out by Khan in the 5th round after Khan landed an uppercut body shot. Judah was unable to answer the referee's 10 count, thus recording his 7th career loss. Khan was ahead 40-36 on all three judges score cards at the time of the knock out. Judah was adamant that the body shot should have been called low and claimed that he had been expecting a mandatory five-minute recovery period.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2011/7/23/2290598/amir-khan-vs-zab-judah-results-knockout-low-blow|title=Amir Khan Stops Zab Judah in Five Rounds|last=Christ|first=Scott|date=2011-07-23|website=Bad Left Hook|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/boxing/14259712|title=Britain's Amir Khan knocks out Zab Judah in Las Vegas|date=2011-07-24|newspaper=BBC Sport|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref>
====Judah vs. García==== Judah's next bout was scheduled for February 9 against undefeated [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] & [[World Boxing Association|WBA (Super)]] Champion [[Danny García]] at the [[Barclays Center]] in [[Brooklyn]], but was subsequently rescheduled to April 27, 2013 due to a rib injury sustained by Garcia during training.
After a heated week of pre-fight confrontations, fans were expecting something special from Danny Garcia vs. Zab Judah. And the fighters delivered, though in an unanticipated fashion. From early on it was clear that the bad blood would not adversely impact the fight, as both men fought strong technical fights.
During the early rounds, Garcia steadily pulled ahead, outboxing Judah throughout. Judah was in serious trouble in rounds 5 and 6, then finally went down in the 8th. From there, things took a surprising turn. Never known for his resolve or ability to turn the fight around late, Judah responded to the knockdown by coming on strong down the stretch. Judah took the last 3 rounds, though his deficit from earlier in the fight meant it wasn't enough and Garcia defeated Judah by unanimous decision (115-112, 114-112, 116-111).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/9219336/danny-garcia-grinds-bloody-win-zab-judah|title=Garcia grinds out win over Judah|newspaper=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2013/4/27/4277312/garcia-vs-judah-results-danny-garcia-wins-decision-scores-brooklyn-showtime-boxing-news|title=Results: Garcia overcomes valiant Judah|last=Christ|first=Scott|date=2013-04-27|website=Bad Left Hook|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref>
===Second return to welterweight=== ====Judah vs. Malignaggi==== Judah fought former welterweight titlist [[Paulie Malignaggi]] December 7, 2013 at the Barclays Center for the vacant [[North American Boxing Federation|NABF]] welterweight title. Judah started well, winning the first three rounds with a sharp jab, also dropping Malignaggi in the second round. The rest of the fight saw Malignaggi hitting quick jabs outpointing Judah. The fight went the 12 round distance as the judges scored it 116-111, 117-110 and 117-110 all in Malignaggi's favor. Due to the lack of action in the fight, the crowd booed as the fight ended. The fight was for the "King of Brooklyn" belt and local bragging rights.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/10101224/paulie-malignaggi-beats-zab-judah-unanimous-decision-welterweight-bout|title=Malignaggi wins unanimous decision vs. Judah|newspaper=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.badlefthook.com/2013/12/8/5187446/judah-vs-malignaggi-paulie-malignaggi-blows-out-zab-judah-in-battle|title=Malignaggi blows out Judah in Battle of Brooklyn|last=Christ|first=Scott|date=2013-12-08|website=Bad Left Hook|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref>
===Return from hiatus=== In early January 2017, Judah announced that he would have his first fight in over 3 years on January 21 when he fights journeyman Jorge Luis Munguia (12-7, 4 KOs) in a scheduled 10 round bout at [[Sun National Bank Center]] in [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], New Jersey. The bout was an Internet-only pay per view.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/18460766/zab-judah-returning-ring-first-2013|title=Zab Judah to fight for first time since 2013|newspaper=ESPN.com|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ringtv.com/479450-zab-judah-age-39-returns-jan-21-with-one-more-title-shot-in-mind/|title=Zab Judah, age 39, returns Jan. 21 with one more title shot in mind - The Ring|date=2017-01-07|newspaper=The Ring|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> As expected, Judah won the bout via 2nd-round TKO. Judah connected with power shots from the opening bell, landed a left hook to the head of Munguia in round 2 which dropped it on his back. The referee stopped the fight at 1 minute and 27 seconds of the round.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/zab-judah-returns-blasts-out-munguia-two-rounds-results--112875|title=Zab Judah Returns, Blasts Out Munguia in Two Rounds - Boxing News|website=www.boxingscene.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldboxingnews.net/2017/01/22/news/zab-judah-39-returns-from-three-year-absence-with-early-tko|title=Zab Judah, 39, returns from three-year absence with early TKO|last=WBN|website=WBN - World Boxing News|access-date=2017-01-22}}</ref> A year later on January 27, 2018, Judah returned to the ring at the Grey Eagle Resort and Casino in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada and fought Mexican boxer Noel Mejia Rincon (21-14-1, 12 KOs) over 10 rounds. Judah's entrance included a light show, as well as showcasing some of the world titles he had won during his career. The fight went the 10 round distance with Judah winning 99-91 on all three judges scorecards. Apart from being hurt once towards the end of round 6 following some body shots, Judah started the first round at a steady pace but controlled the remainder of the fight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/zab-judah-returns-rincon-canada-results--124715|title=Zab Judah Returns, Decisions Noel Rincon in Canada|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-01-31|language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ringtv.com/527381-zab-judah-back-action-outpoints-noel-mejia-rincon-10/|title=Zab Judah back in action, outpoints Noel Mejia Rincon over 10 - The Ring|date=2018-01-28|work=The Ring|access-date=2018-01-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Personal life== Judah has nine brothers and two sisters. Five of his brothers also box, with three of them, [[Josiah Judah|Josiah]], [[Joseph Judah|Joseph]] and [[Daniel Judah]], boxing professionally. Judah's father and trainer, Rastus Jones, is a six-time kickboxing world champion and a seventh degree [[Black belt (martial arts)|black belt]].<ref name="Cotto V Judah">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Cotto V Judah Bio | work = | publisher =Live Fight | date = | url =http://www.livefight.com/news.php?news_id=122&y=2007&m=05 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 18, 2008 }}</ref> Judah's father is an avowed [[Black Hebrew Israelite]] and Judah's family has declared themselves [[Jew]]ish.<ref>[http://www.jewsinsports.org/profile.asp?sport=boxing&ID=250 Judah, Zab "Super"]. Jews In Sports Online. Retrieved on 2008-05-18.</ref><ref>[http://www.braggingrightscorner.com/yjudah.html An Exclusive Interview with Yoel Judah] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708090615/http://www.braggingrightscorner.com/yjudah.html |date=2011-07-08 }}. BraggingRightsCorner.com. Retrieved on 2008-05-18.</ref> Judah thanked "his Lord and Savior [[Jesus Christ]]" after his 2005 fight against [[Cory Spinks|Spinks]].<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3C5U0NP6TWE], at 6:42 on May 11, 2010 HBO video on YouTube.com posted by fightfilms1. Retrieved 2010-06-16.</ref> Zab is now a [[Born again (Christianity)|Born again Christian]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myboxingfans.com/2011/03/zab-judah-makes-a-statement/ |title=Zab Judah Makes a Statement - MyBoxingFans - Boxing News |publisher=MyBoxingFans |date= |accessdate=2013-03-01}}</ref>
In July 2006, he was arrested after a celebrity basketball game at Madison Square Garden on a Family Court [[Warrant (law)|warrant]].<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Zab Judah Arrested | work = | publisher =HHNLive.com | date =July 26, 2007 | url =http://www.hhnlive.com/news/more/161.html | doi = | accessdate =May 18, 2008 }}</ref> In August 2007, Judah became involved in a fight at Stereo nightclub in New York. According to the ''[[New York Daily News]]'', Judah started throwing punches after he was hit first by someone who approached him. Two of the perpetrator's friends then joined in the fight and eventually everyone involved were kicked out of the club. After reviewing the videotape, the club indicated the perpetrators "might have been plotting something."<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Zab Judah in a Fight Outside the Ring | publisher =EURweb.com | date =August 3, 2007 | url =http://www.eurweb.com/story/eur35585.cfm | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 18, 2008 }}</ref>
[[New York City Police Department|New York Police]] linked [[rapper]] [[Fabolous]] to a crew of robbers who targeted Judah twice. According to police reports, the Street Fam Crew, the gang that attempted to rob Judah, is made up of 20 members, all former drug dealers from Fabolous' [[Brooklyn]] neighborhood. In 2006, three men tried to rob Judah as he stood next to his [[Lamborghini]] on West 27th Street at [[Tenth Avenue (Manhattan)|10th Avenue]] in New York City. The three men drove up to Judah in a minivan at about 5 am, and came out. One man pulled a handgun on Judah, and told him to put his jewelry on the hood of his car, but Judah ran instead. The muggers followed in their minivan, but crashed into a tree a block away. All three robbers fled the scene, but one was captured by a [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Homeland Security agent]] on his way to work, and another was grabbed by a nearby cab driver.<ref>{{cite web | last =Vester | first =Mark | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Fabolous' Crew Linked to Zab Judah Robberies | publisher =BoxingScene.com | date =December 10, 2007 | url =http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&id=11639 | format = | doi = | accessdate =May 18, 2008 }}</ref>
Judah also volunteers teaching a nursing assistance class and helps at an adult day care facility treating patients with dementia.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=peM1wj7JVNU</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/zab-judah-now-working-nurses-assistant-helping-patients--123101|title=Zab Judah Now Working as Nurses Assistant, Helping Patients|work=BoxingScene.com|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en-us}}</ref>
